stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on the overworld: adding the first round of shaders (especially fog), modelling a new ‘grape’ bounce object, and fixing older levels that recent engine updates broke.

development_findings.summary: Goal of the session is “finish the first round of adding shaders” to the overworld, concentrating on fog that fades the scene to white near the ship.
development_findings.quote: The goal of today's stream [is to] make some progress in the overworld; we want to finish the first round of adding shaders to this.

development_findings.summary: Old levels were made unplayable by recent engine updates; Kaze is systematically bug-fixing them so they are fun again.
development_findings.quote: These old levels are going to become a lot more playable soon because we broke them over time with engine updates, so making them playable again is very cool.

development_findings.summary: A new bit-flag system (“bitflex”) greatly simplifies level setup and exporting; Kaze wants a one-click script to export the whole repo.
development_findings.quote: I love this new system with the bitflex; this is so convenient. I want to get my repository into a state where I can execute a script to export every[thing].

development_findings.summary: Introduced a bouncing ‘grape’ object: each grape is a separate actor with its own collision, squishy sound, and colour set by shape colour × prim + tex0.
development_findings.quote: I want individual grapes that you bounce off of, and they need to be separate actors.

development_findings.summary: Fog controller now starts at 1 000 (was 970) and is conditionally enabled only after the player crosses the bridge; far-start value tuned to ~13 000 to achieve the white-out effect.
development_findings.quote: We could program the fog controller to make no fog at all while you’re on this side and then when you’re on the other side fog appears—that should work.

development_findings.summary: Design intent: the ‘big overworld’ may be completely barren—textures removed and Mario set to move automatically—emphasising a desolate atmosphere.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking the entire world should just be dead … I think Mario should move automatically so you don't even have to play the game here.

development_findings.summary: Loops in code are being replaced with ticks for better control and stability (“removing all loops, turning all of them into ticks”).
development_findings.quote: We’re removing all loops, by the way—turning all of them into ticks.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes pot, calling it ‘no good’ and advises a viewer to stop.
context_findings.quote: You definitely should stop smoking pot—pot is no good.

context_findings.summary: He finds bug-fixing old content ‘really fun’, indicating personal satisfaction in polishing rather than only creating new assets.
context_findings.quote: It’s actually really fun to work on bug fixes for these.

context_findings.summary: Expresses scepticism toward adding a personal theme song, worried it might be ‘cringe’.
context_findings.quote: How do you make a theme song for yourself that is not cringe?

context_findings.summary: Plans video releases: one this Saturday and another on the 14th of next month, showing ongoing public-facing schedule management.
context_findings.quote: I'm actually planning to upload another video on this Saturday and then another video on the 14th of next month.

zeina.summary: Zeina is currently ‘working on the Penguin Town for course 13’ while Kaze develops other areas.
zeina.quote: She's currently still working on the Penguin Town for course 13.

zeina.summary: Kaze and Zeina watch anime together (‘BNA’), hinting at intertwined personal and professional time.
zeina.quote: I'm currently watching it with Zeina.

key_stories.title: Making the Fog Fade Work
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed the overworld to fade into white only after Mario crosses the bridge. Initial fog settings were wrong, so he rewrote the fog controller logic.
key_stories.challenge: Default fog applied everywhere, ruining visibility and mood.
key_stories.process: Tested various start/end distances; realised he must toggle fog based on player position; changed controller to start at 13 000 only when on far side.
key_stories.outcome: Achieved smooth white-out while keeping near area clear, declaring it ‘kind of cool’.
key_stories.key_quote: We could program the fog controller to make no fog … while you're on this side and then when you're on the other side fog appears.

key_stories.title: Creating the Bouncing Grapes
key_stories.summary: He decided the level needed grape obstacles you can bounce on. He modelled them, chose shading, wrote collision and sound, and integrated them.
key_stories.challenge: Design a playful object that fits the aesthetic and mechanics.
key_stories.process: Modelled a single grape in Blender, used shape colour × prim + tex0, wrote actor code, added squishy grass-like SFX, compiled and tested.
key_stories.outcome: Grapes work in-game; Kaze is pleased: ‘I like the grapes. They're good grapes.’
key_stories.key_quote: I want individual grapes that you bounce off of, and they need to be separate actors.
